articles.headline: Card Act Cleared Up Credit Cards’ Hidden Costs
articles.snippet: Economists found that the Card Act, passed in 2009, saved consumers billions of dollars by cutting through a tangle of credit card fees.
articles.abstract: Economists found that the Card Act, passed in 2009, saved consumers billions of dollars by cutting through a tangle of credit card fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Congress decided to force down the hidden fees that credit card companies collect from their customers. It passed a law called the 2009 Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act — a name chosen so the law would be known as the Card Act.

articles.headline: So Far, So Good for Twitter
articles.snippet: Twitter reached a valuation of $31.7 billion as it began trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, a figure the company will have to justify by showing a profit sooner rather than later.
articles.abstract: Twitter reached a valuation of $31.7 billion as it began trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, a figure the company will have to justify by showing a profit sooner rather than later.
articles.lead_paragraph: Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange called out orders for shares of Twitter for the first time Thursday morning as one of Wall Street’s traditional rituals thrust the young company into the public markets.

articles.headline: Precious Eyes
articles.snippet: Guide dog training is a charity with a high cost, but one that has an incalculable payback.
articles.abstract: Guide dog training is a charity with a high cost, but one that has an incalculable payback.
articles.lead_paragraph: JENNIFER MURRAY woke after a night out with friends and thought her husband was playing a trick on her. She could not see anything and did not believe him when he said it was daytime.

articles.headline: How to Choose a Charity Wisely
articles.snippet: Discriminating givers can turn to services and strategies to make sure their donations will mostly be spent on a charity’s stated mission.
articles.abstract: Discriminating givers can turn to services and strategies to make sure their donations will mostly be spent on a charity’s stated mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONATING to charities this time of year used to be relatively efficient and painless. After watching the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, you plunked some money into a Salvation Army bucket, wrote some checks, contributed some household items and were done.

articles.headline: Balancing Act for India’s Top Banker
articles.snippet: Raghuram Rajan is cutting interest rates to stimulate growth, while talking tough against India’s high inflation rate.
articles.abstract: Raghuram Rajan is cutting interest rates to stimulate growth, while talking tough against India’s high inflation rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Raghuram Rajan, the head of India’s central bank, began his career as an economic theoretician. But a willingness to delve into the mechanics of an economic system may prove to be a bigger asset as he tries to straighten out India’s economy.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: West and Iran Seen as Nearing a Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: Even as the two sides tried to finalize the agreement on Thursday, fissures have widened between the United States and some of its principal allies over the potential pact.
articles.abstract: Even as the two sides tried to finalize the agreement on Thursday, fissures have widened between the United States and some of its principal allies over the potential pact.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — After years of fruitless negotiations, Western and Iranian diplomats are on the verge of an agreement that would freeze Tehran’s nuclear program in exchange for an easing of some economic sanctions.

articles.headline: Hollywood Donors Set to Cast Hillary Clinton in Top Role
articles.snippet: Many powerful donors in the entertainment industry chose Barack Obama over Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2008, but their calculations are different this time.
articles.abstract: Many powerful donors in the entertainment industry chose Barack Obama over Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2008, but their calculations are different this time.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the prelude to the 2008 Democratic presidential primary season, the split between the Hollywood mogul David Geffen and Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton represented an early and embarrassing sign of trouble for Mrs. Clinton.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Another Fire Raises Questions for Tesla
articles.snippet: Federal safety investigators said they would review an accident in Tennessee in which a Tesla Model S caught fire, the third such fire in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: Federal safety investigators said they would review an accident in Tennessee in which a Tesla Model S caught fire, the third such fire in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the third time in six weeks, a Tesla Model S was destroyed by a fire after its battery was damaged, prompting new questions over the design of its advanced lithium-ion batteries.

articles.headline: Cut in Food Stamps Forces Hard Choices on Poor
articles.snippet: With reduced benefits starting this month, many recipients are buying fewer groceries and planning visits to food pantries to tide them over.
articles.abstract: With reduced benefits starting this month, many recipients are buying fewer groceries and planning visits to food pantries to tide them over.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — For many, a $10 or $20 cut in the monthly food budget would be absorbed with little notice.
articles.byline: By Kim Severson and Winnie Hu

articles.headline: At Twitter, Working Behind the Scenes Toward a Billion-Dollar Payday
articles.snippet: The rise of Suhail R. Rizvi, a major Twitter shareholder, illustrates how a new tech investor class with deep Wall Street connections is carving new paths into Silicon Valley’s terrain.
articles.abstract: The rise of Suhail R. Rizvi, a major Twitter shareholder, illustrates how a new tech investor class with deep Wall Street connections is carving new paths into Silicon Valley’s terrain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia looks like a big Twitter winner. So do the moneyed clients of Jamie Dimon.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Rules to Require Equal Coverage for Mental Ills
articles.snippet: The regulations, which the White House sees as part of a push to curb gun violence, will require insurers to cover care for mental health and addiction just like physical illnesses.
articles.abstract: The regulations, which the White House sees as part of a push to curb gun violence, will require insurers to cover care for mental health and addiction just like physical illnesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday will complete a generation-long effort to require insurers to cover care for mental health and addiction just like physical illnesses when it issues long-awaited regulations defining parity in benefits and treatment.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear

articles.headline: CBS to Correct Erroneous Report on Benghazi
articles.snippet: The network acknowledged that it had suffered a blow to its credibility in broadcasting a report with an interview of someone who was never at the scene.
articles.abstract: The network acknowledged that it had suffered a blow to its credibility in broadcasting a report with an interview of someone who was never at the scene.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it prepared to broadcast a rare on-air correction Sunday for a now-discredited “60 Minutes” report, CBS News acknowledged on Friday that it had suffered a damaging blow to its credibility. Its top executive called the segment “as big a mistake as there has been” in the 45-year-old history of the celebrated news program.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Job Growth Eases Fears About Effect of Closing
articles.snippet: Robust job creation in October — 204,000 positions — prompted some usually cautious observers to wonder whether the economy was finally finding its footing.
articles.abstract: Robust job creation in October — 204,000 positions — prompted some usually cautious observers to wonder whether the economy was finally finding its footing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite dysfunction in Washington and a 16-day government shutdown, the economy chugged along in October, surprising many analysts as private sector hiring bounced back after a spring slowdown.
